repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
            Sanitation Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Improved Access to Water
            and Sanitation Services Project for Morocco were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory and grantee
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: the experience in Meknes revealed that the public
            sector could also bear the performance risk and that a
            public utility provider could successfully adopt the
            Output-Based Aid (OBA) methodology to ensure the provision
            of basic services to the neglected segments of the
            population. Organization of awareness and information
            campaigns was crucial to guaranteeing the populations buy-in
            in the social program. Revisiting the operators'
            obligation to address all social issues and encourage the
            active involvement of the local authorities. Addressing the
            poor in informal settlements relies on experience, mature
            knowledge and adequate strategy on the part of the
            operators. Monitoring and evaluation is key to achieving a
            rigorous framework to measure, report, and amend especially
            to ensure successful replication of the Pilot. However,
            information collection should solely aim at directly
            enhancing the project implementation capacity and its outcomes.

docna.cdata!:
Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
            Sanitation Services Project

Morocco - Improved Access to
            Water and Sanitation Services Project

repnme.cdata!:
Innovative expansion of water and
            sanitation services in Morocco

abstracts.cdata!:
Peri-urban illegal settlements, which
            often constitute a substantial portion of major cities, face
            a shortage of safe drinking water and sanitation. The
            Government of Morocco requested a grant from the Global
            Partnership on Output-Based Aid (GPOBA) to pilot the
            introduction of performance-based subsidies to encourage
            service expansion. Between 2007- 2011, the pilot has
            provided subsidized access to water and sanitation,
            benefitting more than 52,500 people to date.

docna.cdata!:
Une approche innovante pour etendre les
            services d'eau et d'assainissement au Maroc

display_title.display_title:
Innovative expansion of water and
            sanitation services in Morocco : Une approche innovante pour
            etendre les services d'eau et d'assainissement au Maroc

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
            Sanitation Services Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Improved Access to Water and Sanitation Services Project for
            Morocco is to provide sustainable access to combined water
            and sewerage services to peri-urban 'quartiers'
            with high levels of 'vulnerable' households. This
            memorandum seeks the approval of the Regional Vice President
            (MNAVP) to extend the closing date of the project by 12
            months from its current closing date of December 31, 2010 to
            December 31, 2011. The performance of the recipients, in
            particular the three implementing operators is satisfactory:
            The project is rated satisfactory for progress towards
            achievement of objective, Overall implementation progress,
            project management, counterpart funding, monitoring and
            evaluation and safeguards. The only change is the extension
            of the closing date of the project by 12 months from its
            current closing date of December 31, 2010 to December 31,
            2011.  The extension is necessary to allow the full
            utilization of the grants. The extension will also give
            ample time to process remaining disbursements, which
            committed their subsidy amount in full in the second and
            third quarters of 2010, respectively. The change does not
            impact the project performance indicators, which remain the
            same. The changes described above do not have a significant
            impact on the original economic, financial, technical,
            institutional or safeguards aspects of the project. The
            Project's development objective remains achievable. The
            extension would give additional time to provide subsidized
            access to services to about 1,870 poor households in the
            Greater Casablanca area, which the remaining subsidy can
            allow connecting under the project.

docna.cdata!:
Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
            Sanitation Services Project : restructuring

display_title.display_title:
Morocco - Improved Access to
            Water and Sanitation Services Project : restructuring

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
            Sanitation Services Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Improved Access to
            Water and Sanitation Services Project is to promote,
            following an output-based approach, the connection to water
            and sanitation services of about 11,300 low income
            beneficiary households selected in disadvantaged peri-urban
            and rural National Initiative for Human Development (INDH)
            neighborhoods in the urban centers of Casablanca, Tangiers
            and Meknes in the territory of the Kingdom of Morocco. The
            change is the extension of the closing date of the project
            by 12 months from its current closing date of December 31.
            2009 to December 31, 2010.  The extension is necessary to
            allow the full utilization of the Grant's proceeds.
            Some delays in the implementation have been due to obstacles
            independent from the three service providers regarding which
            encouraging progress have been noted during the last
            supervision mission. In addition to this, the current
            numbers of household connected do not reflect the current
            progress in the extension of distribution lines within the
            targeted areas which will soon lead to a higher rate of
            household connections. The extension will allow further
            achieving the project's development objective through
            the provision of subsidized access to water and sanitation
            to an additional 8,500 poor households currently without
            services. The restructuring does not introduce any specific
            new risks.

Morocco - Improved Access to Water and

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
            Sewerage Services Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Improved Access to
            Water and Sewerage Services Project in Morocco is to provide
            sustainable access to combined water and sewerage services
            to peri-urban 'quartiers' with high levels of
            'vulnerable' households. The project will be
            coordinated and administered by the Ministry of Interior,
            and implemented by the three incumbent providers of water
            supply and sewerage services in the three selected urban
            centers, namely Casablanca, Tangiers, and Meknes. All
            participating utilities will promote the 'National
            Initiative for Human Development-Global Partnership on
            Output-Based Aid (INDH-GPOBA) connection program' to
            households in the selected 'quartiers', will
            receive applications from individual households, make
            connections and be reimbursed a pre-agreed amount upon
            evidence of a functional and used connection. The pilot
            project will make payments to service providers out of a
            common "OBA fund" that will form the basis for a
            later scale up into a national OBA program.

Morocco - Improved Access to Water and
